[http://www.global2000.at/ Global 2000] |- | ''Belgium (Flanders & Brussels)'' || Friends of the Earth Vlaanderen & Brussel (Friends of the Earth Flanders & Brussels) || [http://www.climaxi.be/ Climaxi.be] |- | ''Belgium (Wallonia)'' || Amis de la Terre Belgique || [http://www.amisdelaterre.be/ Amis de la Terre] |- |''Bosnia and Herzegovina'' |Centar za životnu sredinu (Center for Environment) |[http://czzs.org/ czzs.org/] |- | ''Bulgaria'' || Za Zemiata (For the Earth) || [http://www.zazemiata.org/ zazemiata.org] |- | ''Croatia'' || Zelena Akcija ([[Green Action]]) || [http://zelena-akcija.hr/ Zelena-Akcija.hr] |- | ''Cyprus'' || Friends of the Earth Cyprus || [http://foecyprus.weebly.com/ FoECyprus.weebly.com] |- | ''Czech Republic'' || [[Hnutí Duha]] (Rainbow Movement) || [http://www.hnutiduha.cz/ HnutiDuha.cz] |- | ''Denmark'' || NOAH || [https://noah.dk/ Noah.dk] |- | ''England/Wales/Northern Ireland (EWNI)'' || [[Friends of the Earth (EWNI)]] || [http://www.foe.co.uk/ FoE.co.uk] |- | ''Estonia'' || Eesti Roheline Liikumine (Estonian Green Movement) || [http://www.roheline.ee/ Roheline.ee] |- | ''Finland'' || Maan ystävät (Friends of the Earth) || [http://www.maanystavat.fi/ Maanystavat.fi] |- | ''France'' || Les Amis de la Terre-France |Les Amis de la Terre ([[Friends of the Earth - France]]) || [http://www.amisdelaterre.org/ AmisdelaTerre.org] |- | ''Georgia'' || Sakhartvelos Mtsvaneta Modzraoba (Greens Movement of Georgia) || [http://greens.ge/ Greens.ge] |- | ''Germany'' || [[Bund für Umwelt und Naturschutz Deutschland]] (BUND)|| [http://www.bund.net/ BUND.net] |- | ''Hungary'' || Magyar Természetvédok Szövetsége (National Society of Conservationists) || [http://www.mtvsz.hu/ mtvsz.hu] |- | ''Ireland'' || Friends of the Earth || [http://www.foe.ie/ FoE.ie] |- | ''Italy'' || Amici della Terra (Friends of the Earth) || [http://www.amicidellaterra.it/ AmicidellaTerra.it] |- | ''Latvia'' || Zemes Draugi (Friends of the Earth) || [http://www.zemesdraugi.lv/ ZemesDraugi.lv] |- | ''Lithuania'' || Lietuvos Zaliuju Judéjimas (Lithuanian Green Movement) || [http://www.zalieji.lt/ Zalieji.lt] |- | ''Luxembourg'' || Mouvement Ecologique (Ecological Movement) || [http://mouvement.oeko.lu/ Mouvement.oeko.lu] |- | ''Macedonia'' || Dvizhenje na Ekologistite na Makedonija (Ecologists Movement of Macedonia) || [http://www.dem.org.mk/ Dem.org.mk] |- | ''Malta'' || Moviment ghall-Ambjent ([[Friends of the Earth (Malta)]]) || [http://www.foemalta.org/home/ FoEMalta.org] |- | ''The Netherlands'' || Vereniging [[Milieudefensie]] (Environmental Defence) || [http://www.milieudefensie.nl/ Milieudefensie.nl] |- | ''Norway'' || Norges Naturvernforbund ([[Norwegian Society for the Conservation of Nature]]) || [http://naturvernforbundet.no/ Naturvernforbundet.no] |- | ''Poland'' || Polski Klub Ekologiczny (Polish Ecological Club) || [http://www.pke-zg.home.pl// Pke-zg.home.pl/] |- |''Russia'' |Russian Social-Ecological Union |[http://www.rusecounion.ru/ Rusecounion.ru] |- | ''Scotland'' || [[Friends of the Earth Scotland]] || [http://www.foe-scotland.org.uk/ FoE-Scotland.org.uk] |- | ''Slovakia'' || [[Priatelia Zeme Slovensko]] (Friends of the Earth Slovakia) || [http://www.priateliazeme.sk/ PriateliaZeme.sk] |- |''Slovenia'' |Focus |[http://focus.si/ focus.si] |- | ''Spain'' || [[Amigos de la Tierra]] (Friends of the Earth) || [http://www.tierra.org/spip/ Tierra.org/spip] |- | ''Sweden'' || Jordens Vänner (Friends of the Earth) || [http://www.jordensvanner.se/ jordensvanner.se] |- | ''Switzerland'' || [[Pro Natura (Switzerland)|Pro Natura]] || [http://www.pronatura.ch/ ProNatura.ch] |- | ''Ukraine'' || Zelenyi Svit || [http://www.zelenysvit.org.ua/ Zelenysvit.org] |} == Campaigns == The current campaign priorities of Friends of the Earth Europe are: * [[Climate justice]] and energy * Food, agriculture and [[biodiversity]] * [[Economic inequality|Economic justice]] * [[Resource justice]] and sustainability === Climate justice and energy === Friends of the Earth Europe is "working to create the much-needed, fair and urgent transition to a [[fossil fuel]] free Europe. It wants to deliver a 100% renewable, no nuclear, super energy-efficient, zero-fossil-fuel Europe by 2030."{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/fossilfreeeurope|title=Fossil Free Europe|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}} The organization calls for radical improvements in energy efficiency, an accelerated phase-out of fossil fuels, a dramatic shift towards community-owned renewable energies, and reduced overall resource consumption and lifestyle changes. This often means targeting [[extractive industries]], especially those who are involved in fracking and tar sands extraction.{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/renewable-energy|title=Renewable energy|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/extractive-industries|title=Extractive industries|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/energy-savings|title=Energy savings|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}} === Food, agriculture and biodiversity === The organization has been a key participant in the European movement against GMOs which has been successful in stopping the planting of [[Genetically modified crops|GM crops]] across most of Europe.{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/gmos|title=GMOs|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}} The organization advocates for more environmentally friendly, equitable and sustainable farming. This includes campaigning to reform the European [[Common Agricultural Policy|Common Agricultural Policy (CAP)]] in ways that can mitigate climate change emissions{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/CAP|title=The Common Agricultural Policy|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}} (especially through reducing reliance on soy imports for livestock{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/soy-change-south-america-paying-price-europe-factory-farms-140717|title=Soy change: time to stop South America paying the price for Europe's factory farms|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}}), protect biodiversity, and stop the collapse of family farming in Europe’s agriculture sector. FoEE has also been active in its opposition to EU trade deals, such as the [[Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement|CETA]] agreement with Canada and [[Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership|TTIP]] with the US, because of a belief that those trade deals do not support human rights and the environment.{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/EU-US-trade-deal|title=EU-US trade deal|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}} One of FoEE’s campaigns aims to protect nature and biodiversity by supporting local groups in their preservation initiatives.{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/nature|title=Nature|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}} === Economic Justice === Friends of the Earth Europe’s economic justice program is occupied with the influence of companies over EU decision-making and the economic, social and environmental consequences of corporate practices. It works to expose cases of corporate capture of EU regulation and examples of the influence of corporate interests over EU policy process which often results in a lack of regulation or weak regulation.{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/corporate-capture|title=Corporate capture|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/conflicts-of-interest|title=Conflicts of interest|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/deregulation|title=Deregulation|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}} The program looks into the issue of European companies which have subsidiaries outside of Europe. Such subsidiaries of multinational companies often fail to respect EU laws and workers’ rights when operating abroad, and victims too often do not have access to justice. It campaigns for guarantees that companies abide by the same safety and social standards for their workers and facilities outside of Europe as in Europe; and that European companies are held accountable for their practices outside of Europe, in particular in cases of abuses.{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/corporate-accountability|title=Corporate accountability|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}} In the area of lobby transparency, FoEE looks at how companies exert their influence over and sometimes directly shape decision-making in the EU. It campaigns in favor of transparency in business influence and more balanced representation of stakeholders in EU policy making. FoEE has been active in exposing cases of revolving door scandals, misleading lobby registrations and deceptive lobby practices. It has been lobbying EU Commission and Parliament in favor of stricter EU legislation in order to close the current loopholes and prevent such scandals.{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/lobby-transparency|title=Lobby transparency|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}} ===Resource justice and sustainability=== FoEE recognizes and promotes the environmental, economic and social benefits of reducing Europe’s resource consumption. They focus on reducing Europe’s land, water, materials and carbon use – including the embedded resources Europe consumes beyond its borders.{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/water-use|title=Water use|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/extractive-industries|title=Extractive industries|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/land|title=Land|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}} The organization promotes the reuse and recycling of materials, opposes incineration, and is calling for the full implementation of the [[Sustainable Development Goals]] and the [https://ec.europa.eu/europeaid/policies/european-development-policy/2030-agenda-sustainable-development_en EU 2030 Agenda].{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/materials-and-waste|title=Materials and waste|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}} == School of Sustainability == FoEE’s School of Sustainability project is inspired by the Latin American ''Escuela de la Sustentabilidad.'' Driven by popular education techniques, the project aims to strengthen the regional network of Friends of the Earth Europe, and create common political analyses of system change from a social justice, environmental justice and human rights perspective, and challenge oppression, power and privilege.{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/school-of-sustainability|title=School of Sustainability|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}} == Coalitions == FoEE is an active member of many coalitions working on environmental issues in Europe including: * '''The Green 10''',{{cite web|url=http://www.green10.org/ |title=Green 10 Website |publisher=Green10.org |date= |accessdate=2012-11-08}} consisting of [[BirdLife International]] (European Community Office), [[Climate Action Network]] Europe (CAN Europe), [https://bankwatch.org/ CEE Bankwatch Network],{{cite web|url=http://www.bankwatch.org/ |title=CEE Bankwatch Network Website |publisher=Bankwatch.org |date= |accessdate=2012-11-08}} [[European Environmental Bureau]] (EEB), [[European Federation for Transport and Environment]] (T&E), Health and Environment Alliance, [[Greenpeace]] Europe, International [[Friends of Nature]] (IFN), [[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF]] European Policy Office and Friends of the Earth Europe. * '''The Alliance for Lobbying Transparency and Ethics Regulation (ALTER-EU)''': FoEE is one of the founding and current steering group members of the [http://www.alter-eu.org/ Alliance for Lobbying Transparency and Ethics Regulation] (ALTER-EU), which was launched in Brussels in July 2005. ALTER-EU gathers 160 civil society groups that are concerned by the growing influence of the corporate sector on EU decision-making. * '''The European Coalition for Corporate Justice''' ==Youth Network (Young Friends of the Earth Europe)== {{See also|Young Friends of the Earth}} In 2007 a youth network called [[Young Friends of the Earth|Young Friends of the Earth Europe]] (YFoEE), was established by national Young Friends of the Earth groups affiliated to FoE member groups. YFoEE is an autonomous and self organised youth-led network, with structures and ways of working set and led by young people, yet retains strong links to Friends of the Earth Europe and the [[Friends of the Earth|Friends of the Earth International]] Federation and their mission, vision and values{{cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/youngfoee/index.htm |title=Young Friends of the Earth Europe Website |publisher=Foeeurope.org |date= |accessdate=2012-11-08}} The YFoEE network unites youth organisations and youth groups working on social and environmental justice in Europe, and runs campaigning and educational activities for young people on a European level. It consists of youth member groups in 15 countries from both EU and Non EU countries, including [[Natur og Ungdom]] (Norway),{{cite web|url=http://www.nu.no/ |title=Natur og Ungdom Website |language=no |publisher=Nu.no |date=2012-10-31 |accessdate=2012-11-08}} [[BUNDjugend]] (Germany){{cite web|url=http://bundjugend.de/ |title=BUNDjugend Website |publisher=Bundjugend.de |date= |accessdate=2012-11-08}} or YFoE Ukraine.[http://melp.dp.ua/ YFoE Ukraine Website] The key campaigning topic of the network since 2007 has been advocating for [[climate justice]], in particular opposing what it considers to be false solutions to climate change,{{cite web|url=http://www.carbontradewatch.org/publications/hoodwinked-in-the-hothouse-false-solutions-to-climate-c.html |title=HOODWINKED IN THE HOTHOUSE: False Solutions to Climate Change |publisher=Carbontradewatch.org |date= |accessdate=2012-11-08}} such as nuclear energy, {{cite web | url = http://www.cancun-brussels.org/?p=115 | title = Don’t nuke our climate! | date = December 9, 2010 | publisher = YFoEE}} {{cite web | url = https://www.youtube.com/user/FoEEurope#p/a/u/0/1LF-aHVTY5w | title = YFoEE Cancun in Brussels Nuclear Tour | date = December 8, 2010 | publisher = FoEE YouTube Channel}} and educating young people to create a youth movement for climate justice. In 2010, YFoEE hosted a parallel convergence to the COP16 UN Climate Talks in Cancún, Mexico, in Brussels, Belgium as an alternative forum to the International political negotiations and to build the regional European Youth Climate Movement. {{cite web | url = http://www.cancun-brussels.org/?p=80 | title = Why ‘Cancùn in Brussels’? | date = November 29, 2010 | publisher = YFoEE}} YFoEE has been active as part of the [[Youth Climate Movement]] and youth delegation at the UNFCCC international climate negotiations, and is one of the founding members of European Youth Climate Movement.{{cite web|author=L aura, Sep 30, 2009 3:47 PM |url=http://sites.google.com/site/europeanyouthclimatemovement/ |title=European Youth Climate Movement Website |publisher=Sites.google.com |date=2009-09-30 |accessdate=2012-11-08}} ===Ways of working=== The YFoEE network is supported by a secretariat in the office of FoEE in Brussels, and coordinated by a Steering Group of 8 volunteers, elected from the YFoEE network annually at the Annual General Meeting. Campaigns and events are led and developed by individual volunteers and representatives of member groups who make up working groups.{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/about/how-we-work|title=How we work|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}} ==Revenue== Friends of the Earth Europe receives funding from a variety of government and non-government sources. These include the [[European Commission]] under the ‘LIFE+ regulation’, the European Climate Foundation, Oak Foundation, and Isvara Foundation, amongst others. It also gets membership fees from national Friends of the Earth groups.{{Cite web|url=http://www.foeeurope.org/about/financial|title=Our funding|website=Friends of the Earth Europe|access-date=2017-07-17}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} == External links == * {{official website|http://www.foeeurope.org/}} * [http://www.foeeurope.org/youngfoee/index.htm Young Friends of the Earth Europe Website] * [https://www.youtube.com/FoEEurope Friends of the Earth Europe Youtube Channel] * [http://www.rightsforpeople.org/ "''Rights for people, Rules for Business''" ECCJ's campaign] * [http://www.alter-eu.org/ Alter-EU website] {{Sustainability}} {{Global warming|state=collapsed}} {{Waste}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Friends Of The Earth Europe}} [[Category:Friends of the Earth]] [[Category:Anti-nuclear organizations]] [[Category:Climate change organizations]] [[Category:International environmental organizations]] [[Category:Environmental organisations based in Belgium]]

{{primary sources|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox company | name = General Retailers and Traders Union | type = | traded_as = | predecessor = | successor = | founder = Anthony Grixti | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | fate = | area_served = | key_people = | industry = Voluntary Association | products = | production = | services = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.grtu.org.mt/ Official website] | footnotes = | romanized = | former type = | foundation = 1948 | location_city = [[Valletta]] | location_country = Malta<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.grtu.org.mt/data/ |title=GRTU Official site |accessdate=December 5, 2016 |publisher=''GRTU''}}</ref> | bodystyle = }} '''General Retailers and Traders Union''' (GRTU), or Association of General Retailers and Traders, is an [[Voluntary association|association]] of [[Small business|small- and medium-sized businesses]] in [[Malta]]. It has over 7,000 members coming from 12,000 different business outlets.
It represents the small business community on bodies such as the Malta Council for Economic Development, the Planning Authority, the Advisory Board of the National Organisation, the Fruit and Vegetables Board, the Commission for the Self Employed, the Council for Consumer Affairs and the Traffic Control Board.

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox film | name = Grey Matter | image = | caption = | director = | producer = Scarab Studio, POV Productions | writer = | starring = [[Ruth Shanel Nirere]], Shami Bizimana, Hervé Kimenyi, Jean Paul Uwayezu, Natasha Muziramakenga, Kennedy Mazimpaka | distributor = Scarab Studio Films | released = {{film date|df=yes|2011}} | runtime = 100 minutes | country = [[Rwanda]]
[[Australia]] | language = | budget = | gross = | screenplay = [[Kivu Ruhorahoza]] | cinematography = | editing = Antonio Rui Ribeiro | music = }} '''''Grey Matter''''' is a 2011 Rwandan film directed by [[Kivu Ruhorahoza]].{{cite web|url=http://tribecafilm.com/stories/512c0ffd1c7d76d9a9000724-awards-announced-2011-tri|title=Awards Announced: 2011 Tribeca Film Festival|publisher=Tribeca|accessdate=9 December 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://gasparilla.bside.com/2012/films/graymatter_kivuruhorahoza_gasparilla2012|title=Gray Matter|publisher=[[Gasparilla International Film Festival]]|accessdate=22 March 2012}} == Synopsis == The film tells three stories which are separate and at times connected. In the first one, the young filmmaker Balthazar is looking for money in [[Kigali]] to produce his debut film, ''Le cycle du cafard'', but the government refuses to finance a film based on the aftermath of the [[Rwandan Genocide|genocide in Rwanda]]. In the second, Balthazar's film takes shape and portrays a man, locked up in an asylum, who was an [[genocidaires|assassin]] during the [[Rwandan Civil War|war]]. In the third story, Yvan and Justine, brother and sister, are two young survivors who are trying to rebuild their lives.[http://www.festivalcinemaafricano.org/eng/index.php?pag=vis_film&id_film=838 African, Asian and Latin American Film Festival - Milan] - 22nd edition ([http://www.festivalcinemaafricano.org license CC BY-SA]) == Awards == * [[Tribeca Film Festival]] 2011 * [[Warsaw Film Festival]] 2011 == References == == External links == * {{imdb title|1890465}} [[Category:2011 films]] [[Category:Rwandan films]] [[Category:Australian films]] {{Africa-film-stub}}

{{multiple issues| {{no footnotes|date=April 2017}} {{unreferenced|date=April 2017}} }} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = Intelsat 702 | image = | image_caption = | mission_type = [[Communication satellite|Communications]] | operator = [[Intelsat]] | website = | COSPAR_ID = 1994-034A | SATCAT = 23124 | mission_duration = 15 years design life | spacecraft_bus = [[Spacebus|HS-601]] | manufacturer = [[Hughes Communications|Hughes]] | dry_mass = | launch_mass = {{convert|3695|kg}} | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|17 June 1994, 07:07:19|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Ariane 4|Ariane 44LP H10+]] | launch_site = [[Guiana Space Centre|Kourou]] [[ELA-2]] | launch_contractor = | entered_service = | disposal_type = | deactivated = | orbit_epoch = April 28, 2017 | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[geostationary orbit|Geostationary]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|36,155.5|km}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|36,188.6|km}} | orbit_inclination = 4.4 degrees | orbit_period = 1,455.5 minutes | orbit_semimajor = {{convert|42542|km|mi}} | orbit_longitude = 32.9° E | apsis = gee | trans_band = 26 [[C band (IEEE)|C band]]
10 {{Ku band}} | trans_frequency = | trans_bandwidth = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = | programme = ''Intelsat VII'' | previous_mission = [[Intelsat 701|Intelsat VII F-1]] | next_mission = [[Intelsat 703|Intelsat VII F-3]] }} '''Intelsat 701''' (also known as '''IS-702''' and '''Intelsat 7-F2''') is a [[geostationary]] [[communication]] [[satellite]] that was built by [[Space Systems/Loral]] ('''SSL'''). It is located in the orbital position of 32.9 degrees east longitude and it is currently in an [[inclined orbit]]. The same is owned by [[Intelsat]]. The satellite was based on the HS-601 platform and its estimated useful life was 15 years. The satellite was successfully launched into space on June 17, 1994, at 07:07:19 UTC, using an [[Ariane 4]]4L vehicle from the [[Guiana Space Center]] in [[French Guiana]], together with the satellites [[Defence Research Agency|STRV 1A]] and [[Defence Research Agency|STRV 1B]]. It had a launch mass of 3,695 kg. The Intelsat 702 is equipped with 26 transponders in [[C band (IEEE)|C band]] and 10 in [[Ku band]] to provide broadcasting, business-to-home services, [[telecommunications]], VSATnetworks. == External links == * [http://www.tbs-satellite.com/tse/online/sat_intelsat_702.html Intelsat 702] TBS satellite * [http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/intelsat-7.htm Intelsat 7] Gunter's Space Page * [http://www.satbeams.com/satellites?norad=23124 Intelsat 702] SatBeams {{Orbital launches in 1994}} {{Intelsat}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1994]] [[Category:Intelsat satellites]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}

[[File:Herman Moll Map of Europe.jpg|thumb|350px|After the [[Peace of Westphalia]] in 1648, Europe's borders were largely stable. 1708 map by Herman Moll]]
'''International relations from 1648–1814''' covers the major interactions of the nations of Europe, as well as the other continents, with emphasis on diplomacy, warfare, migration, and cultural interactions, from the [[Peace of Westphalia]] to the [[Congress of Vienna]]. It is followed by [[International relations of the Great Powers (1814–1919)]].
== Diplomacy and warfare == The 17th century, 1601–1700, saw very little peace in Europe – major wars were fought every year except 1610, 1669 to 1671, and 1680 to 1682.<ref>John A. Mears, "The Emergence Of The Standing Professional Army in Seventeenth-Century Europe," ''Social Science Quarterly'' (1969) 50#1 pp. 106–115 [https://www.jstor.org/stable/42858465 in JSTOR]</ref> The wars were unusually ugly. Europe in the late 17th century, 1648 to 1700, was an age of great intellectual, scientific, artistic and cultural achievement. Historian Frederick Nussbaum says it was: :prolific in genius, in common sense, and in organizing ability. It could properly have been expected that intelligence, comprehension and high purpose would be applied to the control of human relations in general and to the relations between states and peoples in particular. The fact was almost completely opposite. It was a period of marked unintelligence, immorality and frivolity in the conduct of international relations, marked by wars undertaken for dimly conceived purposes, waged with the utmost brutality and conducted by reckless betrayals of allies.<ref>Frederick L. Nussbaum, ''The Triumph of Science and Reason, 1660–1685'' (1953) pp 147–48.</ref>
The worst came during the [[Thirty Years' War]], 1618–1648, which had an extremely negative impact on the civilian population of Germany and surrounding areas, with massive loss of life and disruption of the economy and society. Scholars taking a [[Realism (international relations)|"realist" perspective]] on wars and diplomacy have emphasized the [[Peace of Westphalia]] (1648) as a dividing line. It ended the [[Thirty Years War]] (1618–1648), where religion and ideology had been powerful motivating forces for warfare. Westphalia, in the realist view, ushered in a new international system of sovereign states of roughly equal strength, dedicated not to ideology or religion but to enhance status, and territorial gains. The Catholic Church, for example, no longer devoted its energies to the very difficult task of reclaiming dioceses lost to Protestantism, but to build large-scale missions in overseas colonial possessions that could convert the natives by the thousands Using devoted members of society such as the Jesuits.<ref>Norman Davies, ''Europe: A History'' (1996) p 593–94.</ref> According to Scott Hamish, the realist model assumes that "foreign policies were guided entirely by "Realpolitik," by the resulting struggle for resources and, eventually, by the search for what became known as a 'balance of power.'<ref>Scott Hamish, book review in ''English Historical Review'' (Oct 2013) pp 1239–1241.</ref>
Diplomacy before 1700 was not well developed, and chances to avoid wars were too often squandered. In England, for example, King Charles II paid little attention to diplomacy, which proved disastrous. During the Dutch war of 1665–67, England had no diplomats stationed in Denmark or Sweden. When King Charles realized he needed them as allies, he sent special missions that were uninformed about local political, military, and diplomatic situations, and were ignorant of personalities and political factionalism. Ignorance produced a series of blunders that ruined their efforts to find allies.<ref>J.R. Jones, ''Britain and the World: 1649–1815'' (1980), pp 38–39.</ref>
France set the standards for the new professional diplomacy, which were soon emulated by the other powers; the French language became the diplomatic tongue. The professional model slowly spread other national government agencies, and included distinct specified scope of operations, a full-time career oriented professional leadership at the top and middle ranks; a code of ethics and standards of expected behavior; and attractive pay scales and retirement pensions. Expertise was highly valued, although at the very highest level aristocratic status and family connections played an important role. The new bureaucracy preserved its documents carefully and central archives, maintain a professional office staff, and gained a reputation at home and abroad for the quality of its work in expressing both the short term needs and long-term alliances and values of the state.<ref>John C. Rule, "Colbert de Torcy, an emergent bureaucracy, and the formulation of French foreign policy, 1698–1715." in Ragnhild Hatton, ed., ''Louis XIV and Europe'' (1976) pp. 261–288.</ref> King Louis XIV of France worked hard to systematically develop the most sophisticated diplomatic service, with permanent ambassadors and lesser ministers in major and minor capitals, all preparing steady streams of information and advice to Paris. Diplomacy became a career that proved highly attractive to rich senior aristocrats who enjoyed very high society at royal courts, especially because they carried the status of the most powerful nation in Europe. Increasingly, other nations copied the French model; French became the language of diplomacy, replacing Latin.<ref>Gaston Zeller, "French diplomacy and foreign policy in their European setting." in Carsten, ed., ''The New Cambridge Modern History'' vol 5 (1961) p 198–99, 206.</ref> By 1700, the British and the Dutch, with small land armies, large navies, and large treasuries, used astute diplomacy to build alliances, subsidizing as needed land powers to fight on their side, or as in the case of the Hessians, hiring regiments of soldiers from mercenary princes in small countries.<ref>Charles W. Ingrao, ''The Hessian mercenary state: ideas, institutions, and reform under Frederick II, 1760–1785'' (2003).</ref> The balance of power was very delicately calculated, so that winning a battle here was worth the slice of territory there, with no regard to the wishes of the inhabitants. Important peacemaking conferences at Utrecht (1713), Vienna (1738), Aix-la-Chapelle (1748) and Paris (1763) had a cheerful, cynical, game-like atmosphere in which professional diplomats cashed in victories like casino chips in exchange for territory.<ref>Davies, ''Europe'' (1996) pp 581–82.</ref>
==Second Hundred Years' War: France as the pivot of warfare == {{Main|Second Hundred Years' War}} In 1648 France was the leading European power, and most of the wars pivoted around its aggressiveness. Only poverty-stricken Russia exceeded it in population, and no one could match its wealth, central location, and a very strong professional army. It had largely avoided the devastation of the Thirty Years War. Its weaknesses included an inefficient financial system that was hard-pressed to pay for all the military adventures, and the tendency of most other powers to gang up against it.
During the very long reign of [[Louis XIV of France|King Louis XIV (1643–1715)]], France fought three major wars: the [[Franco-Dutch War]], the [[Nine Years' War|War of the League of Augsburg]], and the [[War of the Spanish Succession]]. There were also two lesser conflicts: the [[War of Devolution]] and the [[War of the Reunions]].<ref>John A. Lynn, ''The Wars of Louis XIV 1667–1714'' (1999).</ref> The wars were very expensive but they defined Louis XIV's foreign policies, and his personality shaped his approach. Impelled "by a mix of commerce, revenge, and pique," Louis sensed that warfare was the ideal way to enhance his glory. In peacetime he concentrated on preparing for the next war. He taught his diplomats that their job was to create tactical and strategic advantages for the French military.<ref>James Nathan, "Force, Order, and Diplomacy in the Age of Louis XIV." ''Virginia Quarterly Review'' 69#4 (1993) 633+.</ref> By 1695, France retained much of its dominance, but had lost control of the seas to the combination of England and Holland. What's more, most countries, both Protestant and Catholic, were in alliance against it. [[Sébastien Le Prestre de Vauban|Vauban, France's leading military strategist]] warned the king in 1689 that a hostile "Alliance" was too powerful at sea. He recommended the best way for France to fight back was to license French merchants ships to privateer and seize enemy merchant ships, while avoiding its navies: :France has its declared enemies Germany and all the states that it embraces; Spain with all its dependencies in Europe, Asia, Africa and America; the Duke of Savoy [in Italy], England, Scotland, Ireland, and all their colonies in the East and West Indies; and Holland with all its possessions in the four corners of the world where it has great establishments. France has ... undeclared enemies, indirectly hostile hostile and envious of its greatness, Denmark, Sweden, Poland, Portugal, Venice, Genoa, and part of the Swiss Confederation, all of which states secretly aid France's enemies by the troops that they hire to them, the money they lend them and by protecting and covering their trade.<ref>Quoted in Geoffrey Simcox, ed., ''War, Diplomacy, and Imperialism, 1618–1763'' (1974), pp. 236-37.</ref>
Vauban was pessimistic about France's so-called friends and allies: :For lukewarm, useless, or impotent friends, France has the Pope, who is indifferent; the King of England [James II] expelled from his country; the Grand Duke of Tuscany; the Dukes of Mantua, Modena, and Parma [all in Italy]; and the other faction of the Swiss. Some of these are sunk in the softness that comes of years of peace, the others are cool in their affections. ... The English and Dutch are the main pillars of the Alliance; they support it by making war against us in concert with the other powers, and they keep it going by means of the money that they pay every year to ... Allies. ... We must, therefore, fall back on privateering as the method of conducting war which is most feasible, simple, cheap, and safe, and which will cost least to the state, the more so since any losses will not be felt by the King, who risks virtually nothing. ... It will enrich the country, train many good officers for the King, and in a short time force his enemies to sue for peace.<ref>Quoted in Simcox, pp. 237, 242.</ref>
== Europe 1648–1721 == The European political scene changed in the late 17th century. Warfare was still more powerful influence than demography, economics or diplomacy, so the major changes resulted from a series of large wars. At first France, with the largest population in the West, a well-developed economy, and a good Navy, was predominant.<ref>Carl J. Friedrich, ''The age of the baroque, 1610–1660'' (1952) pp. 246–66.</ref> It lost part of its preeminence in stages during a series of major wars: the Nine Years War, the War of the Spanish Succession, the Turkish wars of 1683–1699 and 1714–1718, and the great Northern war. Europe was largely regionalized, with wars fought either in the West, the North, or the Southeast. By 1700, there were five major states, Britain, France, Spain, Russia, and the Habsburg monarchy (also called Austria, or the Holy Roman Empire). Prussia was emerging primarily because of its aggressive leadership and its advances in the military arts. Spain, the Netherlands, Poland, Venice, Sweden and the Ottoman Empire were declining powers after losses in a series of wars.<ref>Friedrich, ''The Age of the Baroque, 1610–1660'' (1952) pp. 197–245.</ref> The 1659 treaty of the Pyrenees marked Spain's submission to France. The major powers each developed sophisticated diplomatic, military, and financial systems at the national level, with a striking fall-off of the autonomy of regional aristocrats. England, although wracked with an intense civil war (1642–1646), managed to gain strength internationally. Its Royal Navy reigned supreme on the oceans after a [[Anglo-Dutch Wars|series of wars with the Netherlands.]] As an island nation secure from invasion, it could keep its army small, and invest in subsidies to support the armies of smaller countries to maintain its alliances. Its policy was to use diplomacy and enter wars on the weaker side so as to maintain a balance of power, and to thwart the danger of France maintaining its preeminence.<ref>Andrew A. Lossky, "International Relations in Europe," in J.S. Bromley, ed. ''The New Cambridge Modern History'', vol 6 pp 154–192.</ref> ===Espionage=== The 18th century saw a dramatic expansion of espionage activities. It was a time of war: in nine years out of 10, two or more major powers were at war. Armies grew much larger, with corresponding budgets. Likewise the foreign ministries all grew in size and complexity. National budgets expanded to pay for these expansions, and room was found for intelligence departments with full-time staffs, and well-paid spies and agents. The militaries themselves became more bureaucratised, and sent out military attaches. They were very bright, personable middle-ranking officers stationed in embassies abroad. In each capital, the attached days evaluated the strength, capabilities, and war plan plans of the armies and navies. France under King Louis XIV was the largest, richest, and most powerful nation. It had many enemies and a few friends, and tried to keep track of them all through a well organized intelligence system. France and England pioneered the [[cabinet noir]] whereby foreign correspondence was opened and deciphered, then forwarded to the recipient. France's chief ministers, especially [[Cardinal Mazarin]] (1642–1661) did not invent the new methods; they combined the best practices from other states, and supported it at the highest political and financial levels.<ref>William J. Roosen, "The functioning of ambassadors under Louis XIV." ''French Historical Studies'' 6.3 (1970): 311-332. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/286062 online]</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=William James Roosen|title=The Age of Louis XIV: The Rise of Modern Diplomacy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UFAFKiR4HGIC&pg=PA152|year=1976|pages=147–56}}</ref><ref>Jeremy Black, ''British Diplomats and Diplomacy, 1688-1800'' (2001) pp 143-45. [https://www.questia.com/library/120072833/british-diplomats-and-diplomacy-1688-1800 online] </ref>
=== Population and army strength ===
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Main European countries !! Population about 1648!! Army about 1690 |- | France || 15 million || 130 thousand |- | Holy Roman Empire (Austria) || 8 || 50 |- | Italian states || 12 || |- | Low Countries || 3.5 || 73 (Netherlands) |- | British Isles || 7.5 || 80 (England) |- | Scandinavia || 2.5 || 90 (Sweden) |-
