page.title: Satellite television in the United States

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=June 2014}} [[File:SatelliteDishes-5375.jpg|thumb|right|U.S. residential satellite TV receiver dishes]] Currently, there are two primary '''[[satellite television]]''' providers of subscription based service available to '''[[United States]]''' consumers: [[DirecTV]] and [[Dish Network]], which have 21 and 14 million subscribers respectively.<ref>[https://variety.com/2017/biz/news/att-q2-2017-earnings-directv-time-warner-1202506255/ AT&T Loses Record Number of Traditional TV Subscribers in Q2, Drops 156,000 DirecTV Satellite Customers] - Todd Spanger, Variety, 25 July 2017</ref><ref>[https://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/295682/dish-posts-gains-in-total-pay-tv-subs-net-income.html Dish Posts Gains In Total Pay TV Subs, Net Income] - Wayne Friedman, MediaPost, 22 February 2017</ref>
==History== Over the past three decades, various U.S. satellite services have come and gone or combined to form the current primary services. In 1975 [[RCA]] created [[Satcom 1]], the first satellite built especially for use by the then three national television networks ([[CBS]], [[NBC]], and [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]). Later that same year, [[HBO]] leased a transponder on Satcom 1 and began transmission of television programs via satellite to cable systems. Owners of cable systems paid $10,000 to install 3-meter dishes to receive TV signals in [[C band (IEEE)|C band]]. In 1976 [[Taylor Howard]] built an amateur system, which consisted of a converted military surplus radar dish and a satellite receiver designed and built by Howard, for home satellite reception. Taylor's system could be used for receiving TV programs both from American and Soviet [[communication satellite]]s. In 1977 [[Pat Robertson]] launched the first satellite-delivered basic cable service called the [[CBN Cable Network]]. In 1979, the Satellite Home Viewers Act allowed homeowners in the US to own and operate their own home satellite system, consisting of C-band equipment from a multitude of manufacturers who were making parts for systems such as Taylor Howard's, and began a large controversy of which channels could be received by whom.
[[United States Satellite Broadcasting|USSB]] was a direct-to-home service founded in 1981. In the early 1990s they partnered with [[Hughes Electronics|Hughes]] and continued operation until purchased in 1998 by DirecTV.
In 1991 [[Primestar]] launched as the first North American DBS service. Hughes’s DirecTV, the first national high-powered upper K<sub>u</sub>-band DBS system, went online in 1994. The DirecTV system became the new delivery vehicle for USSB. In 1996, [[EchoStar Communications Corporation|EchoStar]]’s Dish Network went online in the United States and has gone on to similar success as DirecTV’s primary competitor. The [[AlphaStar]] service launched in 1996 and went into bankruptcy in 1997. Primestar sold its assets to Hughes in 1999. Dominion Video Satellite Inc's [[Sky Angel]] also went online in the United States in 1996 with its DBS service geared towards "faith and family" until they sold the license to [[EchoStar Communications Corporation]] in 2008 and switched to an IPTV platform.
In 2004, [[Cablevision]]’s [[Voom]] service went online, specifically catering to the emerging market of [[high-definition television|HDTV]] owners and aficionados, but folded in April 2005. The service’s “exclusive” high-definition channels were migrated to the [[Dish Network]] system. Commercial DBS services are the primary competition to cable television service, although the two types of service have significantly different regulatory requirements (for example, cable television has [[Public access television|public access]] requirements, and the two types of distribution have different regulations regarding carriage of local stations).
[[Image:Antenne-toroidale.jpg|right|thumb|160px|90cm multiple-LNA toroidal satellite dish]]
The majority of [[ethnic-language]] broadcasts in North America are carried on K<sub>u</sub> band free-to-air. The largest concentration of free-to-air programming is on [[Galaxy 19]] at 97° W. [[Pittsburgh International Telecommunications]] and [[GlobeCast World TV]] offers a mix of free and pay-TV ethnic channels in the internationally-standard DVB-S and S2 formats, as do others. [[Home2US|Home2US Communications Inc.]] also offers several ethnic channels on SES 1 at 101° W, as well as other free and pay-TV channels. Many religious broadcasters reach the [[Direct To Home|DTH]] and distribution markets with unencrypted DVB-S television and radio channels on Galaxy 19. These channels are available as part of the [[Glorystar]] Satellite Service. Several U.S.-English language network affiliates (representing CBS, NBC, ABC, [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]], [[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]], [[The CW Television Network|the CW]] (formerly [[The WB Television Network|the WB]] and [[UPN]]), [[ION Television|ION Network]] and [[MyNetworkTV]]) are available as free-to-air broadcasts, as are the three U.S.-Spanish language networks ([[Univisión]], [[Unimás]] and [[Telemundo]]). The number of free-to-air specialty channels is otherwise rather limited. Specific FTA offerings tend to appear and disappear rather often and typically with little or no notice, although sites such as LyngSat do track the changing availability of both free and pay channels worldwide.<ref>[http://www.lyngsat.com/ LyngSat tracking]</ref>
On October 7, 2009, [[National Association of Broadcasters|NAB]] TV Board chair [[Paul Karpowicz]] planned to testify before the [[United States Senate|Senate]] [[United States Senate Commerce Subcommittee on Communications, Technology, and the Internet|Communications Subcommittee]] that broadcasters would be willing to allow subscribers of distant signals to continue to do so even if the [[DTV transition in the United States|digital transition]] resulted in those subscribers receiving stations that they could not before. The NAB did oppose offering new distant signals if a digital signal was available. The [[Satellite TV Modernization Act]] had to be passed by the end of 2009. The [[United States House|House]] bill also allowed Dish Network to offer distant signals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/356999-NAB_Won_t_Oppose_Some_Grandfathering_Of_Distant_Signals.php?rssid=20068&q=digital+tv|title=NAB Won't Oppose Some Grandfathering Of Distant Signals|first=John|last=Eggerton|work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|date=2009-10-06|accessdate=2009-10-09}}</ref> On November 5, [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary|Senate Judiciary Committee]] chairman [[Patrick Leahy]] said he hoped for a "short-time agreement" on the bill passed out of committee September 24. If the Senate approves, the House will have to approve the bill, and if the two versions cannot be reconciled, the license to import signals that expires at the end of the year could be extended.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/382942-Leahy_Looks_for_Short_Time_Agreement_on_Satellite_Reauthorization.php?rssid=20068&q=digital+tv|title=Leahy Looks for 'Short-Time' Agreement on Satellite Reauthorization|first=John|last=Eggerton|work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|date=2009-11-05|accessdate=2009-11-10}}</ref> The House version included an agreement with [[Echostar]] that, where possible, all 210 markets could receive signals, and Echostar could once again deliver distant signals.
The [[United States Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation|Senate Commerce Committee]] approved a version of the bill on November 19, without an amendment requiring local signals in all markets in three years, though a study would be conducted on why 30 markets still had a problem. Before Senate approval, the two versions of the bill will have to be reconciled; the Judiciary Committee had a short market fix, while the Commerce committee bill required [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] in [[High-definition television|HD]] sooner.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/389824-Senate_Passes_Satellite_Reauthorization_Bill.php?rssid=20068&q=digital+tv|title=Senate Passes Satellite Reauthorization Bill|first=John|last=Eggerton|work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|date=2009-11-19|accessdate=2009-11-20}}</ref>
The House approved the [[Satellite Home Viewer Reauthorization Act]] December 3. It included both the [[United States House Committee on Energy and Commerce|House Commerce Committee]] and [[United States House Committee on the Judiciary|House Judiciary Committee]] versions and renewed the ability to use distant signals for five years, allowed Dish Network to offer distant signals again, and required 28 markets to receive signals not available locally. The bill also dealt with some [[copyright]] issues and required Dish Network to offer HD noncommercial signals by 2011 instead of 2013.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/417629-SHVRA_Passes_Convincingly_in_House.php?rssid=20065&q=digital+tv|title=SHVRA Passes Convincingly in House|first=John|last=Eggerton|work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|date=2009-12-03|accessdate=2009-12-03}}</ref>
One potential problem: determining who cannot receive a signal is still based on analog rather than digital TV.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/440498-Satellite_Bill_Extension_Said_To_Be_On_Table_In_House.php?rssid=20103&q=digital+tv|title=Satellite Bill Extension Said To Be On Table In House|first=John|last=Eggerton|work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|date=2009-12-15|accessdate=2009-12-17}}</ref>
On February 11, 2010, Senate Majority Leader [[Harry Reid]] said the satellite reauthorization was part of a jobs bill. [[Rick Boucher]], House chairman for [[United States House Energy Subcommittee on Communications, Technology and the Internet|communications and the Internet]], believed the bill would pass. The deadline is March, since it has been extended 60 days.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/448896-Senate_Version_of_Satellite_Bill_Hits_Hill.php?rssid=20068&q=digital+tv|title=Senate Version of Satellite Bill Hits Hill|first=John|last=Eggerton|work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|date=2010-02-11|accessdate=2010-02-25}}</ref> Sen. [[Jim Bunning]] blocked the legislation in the Senate on Feb. 25, even though it passed the House.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/449291-Senate_Fails_To_Pass_Satellite_License_Bill_Extension.php|title=Senate Fails To Pass Satellite License Bill Extension|first=John|last=Eggerton|work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|date=2010-02-26|accessdate=2010-03-23}}</ref> On March 1, 2010, The [[Satellite Television Extension and Localism Act of 2010]], scheduled to expire in 2014, became part of a [[jobs bill]] with help from Sen. [[Patrick Leahy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vermontbiz.com/node/14589|title=Extension of satellite TV licenses included in proposed jobs legislation|publisher=vermontbiz.com|date=2010-03-01|accessdate=2010-03-23}}</ref>
==C band channels== {{Expand list|date=July 2012}} These are a list of the TV Channels that are on C-band satellites that are receivable in North America today. Most Cable TV [[Cable television headend|headends]] today use other bands (i.e., [[Ku-band]]) in addition to C-band. C-band (from the mid-1970s to the late-1990s/early-2000s) was the band the vast majority of cable operators used to receive television channels from. (Ku-band TV satellites were becoming more common around the mid-/late-1980s, very few channels were on them at the time of its launch).

[[Image:Russian South Pole Traverse.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The [[Fourth Soviet Antarctic Expedition]] used three large [[tractor]]s and four [[sledge]]s on the journey from [[Vostok Station|Vostok]] to the [[South Pole]]]] The '''Soviet Antarctic Expedition''' ('''SAE''' or '''SovAE''') ({{lang-ru|Советская антарктическая экспедиция, САЭ}}, ''Sovyetskaya antarkticheskaya ekspeditziya'') was part of the [[Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute]] of the [[Soviet Committee on Antarctic Research]] of the [[Academy of Sciences of the USSR]].
The [[Soviet Union]]'s [[Ministry of Sea Transport]] was responsible for the administration, logistics and supply of the expeditions.
The first Soviet contact with [[Antarctica]] was in January 1947 when the Slava [[whaling]] flotilla began whaling in [[Southern Ocean|Antarctic waters]].
==Stations== <!-- Unsourced image removed: [[Image:Geophysics house at molodozhnoy.jpg|thumb|right|270px|A building for [[geophysics]] at the [[Molodezhnaya Station (Antarctica)|Molodyozhnaya Station]].]] -->The first Soviet Antarctic station, ''[[Mirny Station|Mirny]]'', was established near the [[coast]] on February 13, 1956. This was added to in December 1957 by another station, ''Vostok'' built inland near the south [[geomagnetic]] pole.
===Year-round stations=== * [[Mirny Station|Mirny]] (established February 13, 1956) * [[Vostok Station|Vostok]] (established December 16, 1957) * [[Novolazarevskaya Station|Novolazarevskaya]] (established January 18, 1961) * [[Molodyozhnaya Station (Antarctica)|Molodyozhnaya]] (established January 14, 1963) * [[Bellingshausen Station|Bellingshausen]] (established February 22, 1968) * [[Leningradskaya Station|Leningradskaya]] (established February 25, 1971) * [[Russkaya Station|Russkaya]] (established March 9, 1980) * [[Progress Station|Progress]] (established April 1, 1988)
===Summer stations=== *[[Komsomolskaya (research station)|Komsomolskaya]] (established November 6, 1957) *[[Pionerskaya Station (Antarctica)|Pionerskaya]] (established May 27, 1956) *[[Druzhnaya I]] (on the [[Filchner Ice Shelf]] in the [[Weddell Sea]]) *[[Druzhnaya II]] (on the Weddell Sea) [[Image:1966 CPA 3318-3320 triangle.png|thumb|320px|10 Years of Soviet Research in Antarctica, 1966 [[USSR]] [[postage stamp block|stamp block]]]]
===IGY stations=== List of stations in use during the [[International Geophysical Year]]. *[[Sovetskaya (Antarctic Research Station)|Sovetskaya]] *[[Pole of inaccessibility (Antarctic research station)|Pole of inaccessibility station]]
==Expeditions== {{Main|List of Antarctic expeditions by the Soviet Union}}
The Soviet Union engaged in expeditions to Antarctica from 1955 to its [[dissolution of the Soviet Union|dissolution]]. After this, the Soviet Antarctic stations were taken over by [[Russia]].
==See also== {{portal|Antarctica|Soviet Union}} * [[Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute]] * [[List of Antarctic expeditions]] * [[Soviet and Russian manned drifting ice stations]] * [[List of Russian explorers]] * [[Zapadnoye Lake]]

(2012) [Conference Edited] * Gan, I, 'The first practical Soviet steps towards getting a foothold in the Antarctic': the Soviet Antarctic whaling flotilla Slava, Polar Record, 47, (240) pp. 21–28. {{ISSN|0032-2474}} (2009) [Refereed Article] * Gan, I, Soviet Antarctic plans after the International Geophysical Year: changes in policy, Polar Record, 46, (3) pp. 244–256. {{ISSN|0032-2474}} (2009) [Refereed Article] * Gan, I, The reluctant hosts: Soviet Antarctic expedition ships visit Australia and New Zealand in 1956, Polar Record, 45, (232) pp. 37–50. {{ISSN|0032-2474}} (2009) [Refereed Article] * Gan, I, Will the Russians abandon Mirny to the penguins after 1959... or will they stay?, Polar Record, 45, (233) pp. 167–175. {{ISSN|0032-2474}} (2009) [Refereed Article] * Gan, I, The Soviet Preparation for the IGY Antarctic Program and the Australian Response: Politics and Science, Bolet%#237;n Antártico Chileno 2nd SCAR Workshop on the History of Antarctic Research, 22–22 September 2006, Santiago, Chile, pp. 60–70. {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox film | name = The Miner | image = The Miner (film).jpg | caption = Film poster | director = [[Hanna Antonina Wojcik Slak]] | producer = Sinisa Juricic
Miha Knific | writer = Hanna Antonina Wojcik Slak | starring = [[Boris Cavazza]] | music = Amélie Legrand
[[Damir Imamovic]] | cinematography = Matthias Pilz | editing = Vladimir Gojun | distributor = 2i Film | released = {{film date|2017|9|15|df=yes}} | runtime = 98 minutes | country = Slovenia | language = Slovene | budget = | gross = $10,252 (Slovenia){{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/intl/?id=_fTHEMINER01&country=SI&wk=2017W41&id=_fTHEMINER01&p=.htm|title=The Miner |work=[[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=30 October 2017}} }} '''''The Miner''''' ({{lang-sl|'''Rudar'''}}) is a 2017 Slovenian [[drama film]] directed by [[Hanna Antonina Wojcik Slak]]. It was selected as the Slovenian entry for the [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]] at the [[90th Academy Awards]], but it was not nominated.{{cite web|url=https://english.sta.si/2430040/-miner-slovenian-candidate-for-foreign-language-oscar |title="Miner" Slovenian candidate for foreign language Oscar |work=STA |date=19 September 2017 |accessdate=19 September 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/oscars-slovenia-selects-miner-foreign-language-category-1041203 |title=Oscars: Slovenia Selects 'Miner' for Foreign-Language Category |work=The Hollywood Reporter |first=Vladimir |last=Kozlov |date=19 September 2017 |accessdate=20 September 2017}} This film follows the true story of a miner, who discovers thousands of executed people in [[Barbara Pit massacre]]. ==Plot== Alija discovers thousands of bodies of people executed during [[World War II]] in an abandoned mine. His employer, wanting to sell the mine, pressures him to keep quiet, but he risks his job by alerting police. ==Cast== * [[Boris Cavazza]] * [[Jure Henigman]] * [[Leon Lučev]] * Tin Marn * Marina Redzepovic ==See also== * [[List of submissions to the 90th Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film]] * [[List of Slovenian submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|6213994|The Miner}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Miner, The}} [[Category:2017 films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:Slovenian films]] [[Category:Slovene-language films]] {{Slovenia-film-stub}} {{2010s-drama-film-stub}}
